The puffs themselves were not the best I had ever had but when you top anything witha rich and creamy ice-cream-like PB mousse and a delicious strawberry sauce...who cares?!?Hit the pocketbook a little hard, but this is a must visit for any self-proclaimed foodie.

We sat at the back bar which I'm glad we did. It's quieter and you have more room. I highly recommend going with the chefs tasting! You get to sample a lot of the menu and try food you normally wouldn't. You will definitely not leave hungry! All the food we had tasted great & service was even better. We will come back for sure!

This place actually holds up to its incredible reviews. The food was fantastic. The wait staff was even better. We got there early to sit at the bar and had the best time. If you can sit at the bar, the staff will keep you enjoying every second of your evening.

I sent this a week ago to Mr. Hughes and his restaurant group. Without a response from him, I feel compelled to post this:Mr. Hughes,Your website and that of Garde Manger does not allow customers to send email messages. I want you to know as a former sous-chef and server, I compliment staff when they deserve it, and more importantly, tip very well. My dinner experience on August 4th at Garde Manger was really quite bad. I share this because if my name was involved with this restaurant I would want to know these details:-My friends were in town from Toronto and wanted to try your restaurant. They booked 30 days in advance. We were seated almost an hour late without an apology and even a recognition that the restaurant was running behind. The greeter, a man with a close-cropped haircut, actually clapped his hands and said 'Come on guys!' while literally waving us into the restaurant (at this point we had come back after having a drink elsewhere and still had to wait). He had said he would text us and never did. I wish I had taken that as a sign.-The restaurant was incredibly hot. Later in the meal someone came to open the front window which helped, but your HVAC was clearly not functioning properly.-The waitress was curt. I'm not someone who expects a server to 'smile' or anything, but there was a cool disdain with how we were treated (I was the one man surrounded by 5 women in my group, and they all commented on this, so I was not alone). Questions were answered in a very curt manner, as in, 'Why don't you already know this?'. She was simply not that helpful or kind in serving us. She also said she would send a sommelier to the table and never did, even though my friend asked to speak to one.-We ordered some dish that was supposed to contain fried halloumi cheese. There was none in the dish. We were told by three people serving us, 'Well it's breaded so you did not taste it.' We stated we knew what halloumi was, and there was none in the dish. We were then given a tiny bowl of fried halloumi with our next dish. That was just in bad taste on behalf of your team, and it's when I started to get pretty irked. It was as if the chef was saying, 'Here's your halloumi, you jerks.'-Even for a fine-dining establishment, the courses were spread out too far apart. We were in your restaurant for over 3 hours for the 'simplified' tasting menu. This was too much.-Our waitress clearly went on an elongated break after the main service was finished. Our digestivos took an agonizing period to arrive to the table - like 20 minutes or more. At this point we were all pretty flummoxed.  Your bar was bumping so much I felt like I was in a supper club.-I did smell a lot of pot wafting through the air during the service -- it easily could've been from outside but some of your staff seemed out of sorts. Some of your kitchen staff seemed to be on stronger stuff than pot. They came over to the table to serve courses and were loud, jittery and too 'in our faces'. Again, I've worked in this industry and seen some things. I can't know for sure but it just didn't look good. -I gave an 8% tip, very low for me. I wish I had given zero, because I woke up at 6:30am and vomited up the tuna tartar. While none of my other friends were that sick, they stated that they all felt 'off'. Maybe I'm more sensitive, or maybe I got the worst dose, but the intense heat of your restaurant and the raw fish flying around just do not jibe well. I eat raw fish and seafood all the time, and I didn't drink any more than usual. It was the tuna.I won't be visiting your restaurant again. I had once been there on business and had a nice time, but this experience turned me off for good.Reading Bourdain's 'The Nasty Bits' after his passing last month, I came across lots of essays about celebrity chefs losing control over their craft in becoming separated from the front lines of their kitchen. I hope this is the case with your place because I have to say that I did not feel welcome in your restaurant. I saw others come in and get hugs from the greeter, escorted straight to seats and served like they were family. This type of vibe at the front door clearly permeates through the core of the establishment. Your staff have made this 'their party', and not the guests' party. I urge you to take action.Very Sincerely,Philip

This was recommended to us by hotel concierge and it didn't disappoint. We were struggling to decide what to eat and as we were sat at the bar the wonderful bar man (I think his name was Vito but it was a couple of weeks back and I'm not totally sure!) said he would order us a tasting menu. We left the choices up to him and it was probably the best meal I've had in years. Everything was delicious and I'd drive the 6 hours it took us to get to Montreal just to have dinner there!The drinks were also fantastic, as was the ambience and music. This is not a kid friendly place but awesome for a dinner with friends or as a date night.

This was probably one of the best dining experiences I ever had. What a fun, totally unpretentious place. The service was amazing, the food totally original and incredibly delicious... it was the kind of delicious that my wife and I took our first bite of our first dish at the same time and looked at each other wide eyed with disbelief and absolute pleasure. Without question, one of the best restaurants I have ever been to. If you like fun and delicious things, this is the place for you!

Wow...Chuck knows his seafood!  It's not a cheap meal for sure ...but you get what you pay for.  This was very memorable...started with ahi tuna with fennel and tomatoes and had scallops with lentils, radicchio and crispy sweet potatoes for a main.  Both amazing and unlike most high end places...the flavours comes without high doses of oil and salt.  Definitely healthier than most restaurants you'll eat at.  Great service and great atmosphere!  The only reason I would say 4.5 stars is price...but again, it's worth it to spend to money for special occasions.  Chuck Hughes' rep is well earned!

Famous for the lobster poutine that beat Iron Chef Bobby Flay, the other menu items here are just as good and mostly as opulent. The poutine can be a meal of its own due to the size and heaviness of it. Lobster and poutine were meant to go together and it's amazing that no one else has thought of it. The gravy and curd go well with the succulent meat. The guinea hen, a meal meant for two, could also fill a family with the decadent truffle and foie gras stuffed inside. It's classic French technique with modern Quebecois ingredients through and through. The meat on the bird was deliciously moist and tender, imbuing flavor from the truffle and foie gras into the meat and skin. The root veggies it came with were a little bland, likely because they imparted most of their flavor into the hen. The bread served was also memorably tasty. There wasn't much of a beer menu, but the wine list was top notch with a good selection on both the bottle and glass lists. Service was very friendly, especially at the bar where it felt very personable. The ambiance is a bit hunting lodge like with wood features and mounted animals. Make a reservation if possible as very few tables are left for walk ins and it is constantly busy.

If I could give 10 stars, I would. BEST RESTAURANT IN MONTREAL. And we have had some excellent food in this city. The food was beyond words exceptional quality and we had food restrictions they had to work around, too (husband is allergic to shellfish and I'm pregnant, so can't eat anything raw). We sat at the bar and had Sam as our bartender. We pretty much let him direct our choices, which was the best decision ever. The music was fantastic and everyone was incredibly friendly. The menu changes daily, based on what's fresh, and they have some choices not listed on the menu boards. We can't wait to come back to Montreal and come back here!
I'm from Chicago visiting a supplier. No BS hands down the best restaurant I've ever visited. If you want authentic, passionate food, different tastes holy shit this is the place!

Great food, perfect atmosphere.  We went for dinner here on Saturday night.  Although the online booking site said there were no reservations, I called, left a voicemail and the hostess promptly called me back to offer counter seats. I am sooooo glad we took them. Sitting at the counter gave us the opportunity to meet David, the bartender, and to watch him make fabulous drinks all night.  He was chatty, but not at all intrusive and had great recommendations. He most certainly added to our experienceand makes an epic old fashioned cocktail. For starters, we had the lobster poutine and the endive salad. The poutine was everything we were dreaming of and more.  For main courses, we had the beef chuck and the duck breast. Both were outstanding. Perfectly portioned, culinary marvels. For dessert we had the chocolate mousse with grapefruit/passion fruit glaze.  Absolutely mouth-watering.  Can't wait to go back!!

Most underwhelming dining experience I have ever had. Lobster Poutine is the best dish? There was barely any lobster and you can eat poutine at any other bar in Montreal.  I have had better poutine at bars. The crab dish came from the miscues off Red lobster's reject menu, and the oysters were good, but isn't that credit to the fish monger? The whole chicken was mediocre, shrimp risotto was a recipe from Paula Dean, and the short rib tasted like a rubber tire. The deserts were not bad. Prince point is outrageous, for a Joe Beef knock off. Go to Petit Bourgundy for the real thing and don't waste your time here.The servers were on point, and it's shame that they work there.

Walked by last night after a really busy & tiring day.  Drawn in by the vibe, we were not planning on falling in love.  But, from the moment we walked in it was exceptional.  Grilled octopus & potato starter was perfect.  BIson tartare was unique & flavorful.  The Arctic Char with toasted Israeli couscous was so fresh & perfectly balanced.  And, exceptional wine list.

I had intended to eat at Le Bremner but it was closed so I decided on Le Garde Manger. I was worried that there was too much hype and if wouldn't be worth it, but boy was I wrong. It was amazing from start fo finish. The service, the atmosphere, the food, the wine and just the overall experience make me want to go back. I had the pork belly to start and the seared scallops as entree and my only regret is I wasn't with my boyfriend so I could have him order the other entree i wanted to taste! I was in town for work so dined alone at the bar (also a great experience getting to watched tue seafood platters and drinks get made), but definitely recommend going as a couple so you can try more options!

Small venue, big flavor. Homie vibe as you walk in there is a nice sense of ole Montreal in the brick veneer. The staff was friendly and there was an eclectic collection of seafood based fusion plates to try. That night I disregarded the house recommendation for seafood and went with the pork tenderloin... and let me tell you, I regret nothing. It was the best pork tenderloin I ever tried. Ever. The wine selection was great, and the cozy ambiance was just what the doctor ordered for my party of 4. They take reservations, and I do recommend that you call in advance on the weekends. When we left the place was packed. Great experience, be prepared to spend s lil $$$, 5 stars.
Birthday dinner at GM was woth the trip to Montreal. Chuck Hughes second resturant is awsome.  They menu has a big sea food presences. If your thinking of going make a reservation well in advance.

Been wanting to go here for a while, so I am somewhat disappointed that it didn't exceed my expectations. We started with the lobster poutine. It was good except for the bits of lobster shell in it.  We also ordered the lobster risotto which was good but nothing special. Again this had bits of lobster shell.  The sous vide short ribs were good but then again not blown away. This had a small bit of bone attached to one of the ribs. Unpleasant surprise while chewing but considering the other 2 courses had unpleasant bits in them as well it shouldn't have come as a surprise.  Overall I wouldn't recommend it as there are plenty of other restaurants in Montreal that Id rather try than come back here again.

You've heard the rumors, and they're all true.  It's near impossible to get a reservation here, and you have to be fairly violent to snag any of the first-come-first-served tables right when they open.  Your best bet is to abandon your family and come here alone to get one of the few spots at the bar.  Tell your family you're not feeling well, and that you're going to just get room service, and politely suggest they take their time eating at...wherever they're going to eat...and then sneak out and enjoy an experience you can never tell them about.It was easier for me because I was traveling solo for work, which is another convenient way to get a spot.  The host was very nice, and the bartender was super friendly, not only providing fantastic service, but also adding the right amount of interaction without being too distant nor chatty.  He also provided some great wine recommendations and got all of us solo bar patrons to chat with one another.I know what you're thinking.  Shut up, Mike, I'm hungry and all of this reading is costing me on the expensive Canadian data plan that I purchased at the airport.  Fine.I had a pretty incredible plate of beef short ribs that were perfectly marinated and fall-off-the-bone tender.  But anything you get here will be prettttttty great.Don't plan to go out after eating here.  Embrace the wonderful, wonderful food coma.Food: 5/5Value: 4/5Service: 5/5Atmosphere: 4/5

Good food, good service, good experience!I wanted to try this restaurant for so long and tonight we finally went there. We were sitting at the bar which was pretty tight but that's ok. The lobster poutine was divine. Absolutely the best poutine in the world. The seafood platter was awesome too, paired with their special sauce, I just want more and more!We got the tilefish as main dish. Awesome balance of flavour with carrot, gravy-like sauce and some crunch stuff. In conclusion, expensive but tasty!

Ok yes expensive but work every penny. I haven't had a meal this good in a while. David out waiter was amazing, all his recommendations were excellent.  The bread is divine...like you want to eat it 24/7.  If you want to spent money and leave happy...make reservations. So worth it...the seafood...amazing

Probably one of the best meals I've had ever , service was excellent or better !!!  Atmosphere awesome food amazing on point we started with a seafood platter all awesome then we had had some apps.  Lobster poutine, ect all we're crazy good & we split up dinner so I never thought a pork chop could be that good but dam. It was.  Rossito was awesome sauce    & all our cocktails were great too.  So yeah if you go to Montreal yeah go here make a reservation & go !!!!!!

The food was spot on. Had the seafood tower and me and my guest shared the lobster poutine and the steak.  The staff showed attention to detail and the food was great. A little but pricey but every know and then you have treat yourself.

We came here as a date night on a Saturday night for a 6 PM dinner.  I'd originally only been able to get a bar seat but when they called the day before they were able to accommodate for a regular table.  The restaurant was unassuming from the outside.  We were seated immediately and our server was prompt.  He was very good at explaining how the menu was and making recommendations.  I asked about their infamous lobster poutine and he told me how after 11 years it came off the menu.  We started with the zucchini salad.  Anytime there's zucchini flower on the menu I am drawn to it.  The flower was stuffed with ricotta and the zucchini salad was very light and refreshing.  Our next appetizer was the spicy jerk crab.  Our server warned us it's super spicy and it was but it was good!  Decent sized legs.  My mouth was on fire lol.  Thankfully they gave us time to get the spiciness out of our mouths.  Then we shared the scallops and pork belly.  This was delicious.  Scallops were very good sized and the charred corn beneath was nice.  Next was the pork tenderloin on cheese grits.  The grits weren't overly cheesy which was good.  The cabbage was very nice.  The overall flavours were great.  We were too stuffed for dessert.  Their bread looked good and the couple beside us was devouring it but we didn't have enough room to have bread to start lol.  Definitely a great dining experience and would definitely go back!  The vibe and food and service were all excellent.  I just wasn't able to pay with my Visa giftcard that I was given as a gift.

Hubby ordered the seared foie gras with duck confit sitting on a buckwheat waffle and was really happy with it. While seared foie gras and duck confit are French components, the maple gastrique and buckwheat waffle were a great way to inject a little Canadiana. I had a difficult time choosing my starter because I wanted to eat everything but in the end I ordered the octopus with fingerlings, crème fraîche, chorizo, and butternut squash purée and I didn't regret it for a second.Hubby went with the short rib for his main. The meat, vacuum-packed and slow-cooked at a low temperature for 60 hours at 60 degrees, had great beefy flavour and a melt in your mouth texture. It was served upon a large pile of Gouda mashed potatoes and this made hubby a happy man. For some reason I was really feeling the seafood so I ordered the seared scallops with leek, romanesco, speck, and more butternut squash purée. Everything was cooked, seasoned, and plated to perfection but I was left a little bit hungry. I had chosen two fairly light dishes on purpose so that I could end our dinner on a sweet note. While all the options sounded tempting, I was drawn to the s'mores dessert because it involved marshmallows and I am a sucker for marshmallows. The decadent chocolate brownie, topped with warm, gooey marshmallow and graham crumb and vanilla ice cream was the perfect ending.We left Garde Manger well satisfied and ready to paint the town 'rouge'
Hard to get reservation but worth it. A very nice pricy place. I ordered the veal cheek risotto dish and my brother ordered the monk fish a much to try very tasty meals.

I have saved my 700th review especially for Chuck. Last weekend in Montreal I had the pleasure of finally dining at Garde Manger. We had booked a 7pm reservation on Saturday night (booked 1 month in advance to the day, just to be sure)I want to say everything about the evening was absolutely perfect. The restaurant is small, maybe 15-20 tables in total, with a small bar at the front and an open kitchen at the back. Exposed brick walls, dark interior, incredible large kitschy chandelier type light fixture above the bar. Music was just the kind you expect after watching an episode of Chuck's Day Off - we heard Sublime, Guns N Roses and even the Hockey Night in Canada theme song.The waiter (gorgeous, of course) was attentive, friendly and knowledgeable of the menu. The food was as amazing as expected. We had two appetizers - a peach salad of some kind with charcuterie, nuts and some type of gorgonzola, and a toast of some sort with chanterelles and cheese on top. Both were excellent.The mains was where we went astray. We made the mistake of choosing 2 seafood dishes - a scallops dish and an octopus dish. Both were genuinely amazing, but the price point was absolutely ridiculous. Sorry Chuck. $37 for 3 scallops and $35 for about 100 gram piece of octopus, I was really just expecting more. Even the appetizers (priced at $12-$14) were larger portions. Folks sitting nearby did order the short ribs and the portion was much more reasonable all things considered. We shared a peach parfait to end the evening, which again was delicious.The total bill came to $230 with tax and tip. That included the cheapest bottle of red they had ($45?), two mains, two appetizers and 1 dessert. Overall an incredible dining experience with perfect food, just marred slightly for me by the portion sizes of the spendy main dishes. I think Chuck owes me some more seafood, to be honest.

We made last-minute reservations here after receiving a glowing recommendation from a local couple - all that was available was a late seating at the bar, but I'm very glad we took it! We did have to wait about 10-15 minutes past our reservation time to get seated, but the host did his best and there was a nice fire to keep us warm in the waiting area. Our seat ended up being at the oyster bar, which not everyone would enjoy, but we found it interesting. It was great to witness employees who actually seem to like their jobs and the food served!We decided to have the $80 chef's choice tasting option, and although our total bill with drinks and gratuity ended up coming to about $300, I feel that it was a very good value for the amount, quality, and variety of food we were given. Dishes varied from a chilled seafood platter (my first time having freshly grated horseradish!) to endive salad to a sort of surf and turf main dish. Everything was fresh and tasty - the only thing that we felt could have been better was the pork belly dish. The wine recommendation was right on. Dessert included an apple crisp with brown butter ice cream and two very decadent chocolate peanut butter puffs.
You won't be sorry if you go with the chef's choice. The seafood platter is a sampling of all they have. Bring an appetite and be adventurous! We had an outstanding experience!

After watching Mr. Hughes cook on his day off many times, I decided Garde Manger was a place I'd definitely have to hit up when I was in Montréal. It did not disappoint! Got an excellent short rib, chili crab, and a smore's ice cream dessert that was heavenly.Staff were awesome - great food and really fun.Recommended!

Extremely disappointed. They took their signature item, lobster poutine off the menu. A restaurant has a right to change its menu however when you remove a dish that is world famous and a destination dish and you do not have a current menu posted online, you can expect customers to be disappointed. Wound up having a pretty good but extremely overpriced for portion size scallops dish. I live in NY and can get great scallops dishes in 15 restaurants. Having your mouth set for a famous, award winning dish to find it had been removed soured me on the whole experience. And again, based on price, portion size, and overall quality, I would not recommend this restaurant.

I knew that the next time I came to Montreal I was going to pop my Garde Manger cherry.My first time was everything I had hoped for, and more!We made a reservation (smart idea), and were seated right away at the bar. Perfect place to sit for a small group of 2 or 3! Must have - Lobster Poutine. One might think this is probably Chuck Hughes' most overrated dish...but trust me, it was well due the accolades! Absolutely delicious. Poutine with just the right amount of "fishiness" added to the gravy, curds, and frites. We also had the Albacore Tuna and Crackling Pork (equally amazing) and the Pierogies & Pork Belly (yum). Service was great. Ambience was perfect. It's a great feeling when a restaurant can live up to high expectations! I can't wait to come back again and try other items!C'est tres tres bonne!!!!!

After drooling over internet pictures of this place for years,  I finally had the chance to try Chuck Hughes restaurant.  We had reservations for a Thursday night, came in and were seated immediately.  The service was top notch, our waitress knew everything on the menu...scratch that as there were no physical menus.  Just two black boards on the walls, one in English and the other in French.  Because the English board was further away, she just started translating the French one for us, describing in great detail the ingredients of all the dishes and how they were prepared all of the top of her head.  I was impressed by her knowledge and passion for the things she described.  Since we had a group of 6, she altered the menu so everyone would have a decent bite of every dish ordered.  Lobster Poutine - great! good chunks of lobster, but quite pricey at $19 for regular size and $28 for a large.Oysters - were fresh and tasty.  we had a mix of 6 different ones in season that I can't recall anymore.Braised Short Rib - nothing memorable if that says anything about itSeafood Risotto - very flavourable, but way too salty and I LOVE salty food.    Scallops with bacon and black truffle - These were plumb and juicy

The Smarty Pants Canadian Cousin was ecstatic to get a reservation for Garde-Manger for my visit.  "I had to stalk their website for a month to get this," she exclaimed.  Let's hope this Rude Vile American Cousin didn't embarrass the Smarty Pants Canadian Cousin too much.-- BREAD - With housemade cream cheese spread.  So good that they should charge for it.  MUST GET (obviously).-- OYSTERS - Village Bay ($2.5) , Wellfleet ($3.25), Standish ($3.75), Cape Spear ($2.75), Coleville Bay ($3.25) - Arranged specifically in increasing order of flavor/sweetness.  Personally, for the sheer presentation, get the impressive seafood platter instead.-- $15 GIANT CAESAR - Get their signature drink simply for the WOW factor.  I'm not a huge Bloody Mary fan, but the spicy kick (pepper on the rim and horseradish on the jabbed spoon) and the dangling giant snow crab claw made this drink impressive.  MUST GET.-- $19 POUTINE DE HOMARD - The famous lobster poutine with lobster gravy was what we came for, and although good, it wasn't as great as those at the cheaper hole-in-the-wall poutine places.-- $13 COD ACRA - The cod fritters were amazingly delicious - light and fluffy.  MUST GET.-- $15 SMOKED SALMON - Being just smoked salmon, this was the least favorite dish of the night - which says more about how amazing everything else was.-- $24 WAFFLE FOIE GRAS - Strange yet delicious pairing - a generous helping of savory seared foie gras and braised short rib over a honey-sweetened waffle.  Yes, it was as amazing as it sounds - the best dish of the night.  MUST GET.-- $35 PETONCLES - The scallops were gigantic - the size of hockey pucks, EH!  The perfectly cooked risotto was wonderful with the heirloom veggies.  The sauce was very good.  GET IT.The attentive service was exquisite - the courses were paired off according to complementing tastes, and every plate was accompanied by a thorough introduction to the dish.  (Note: Menu on the chalkboard changes constantly.)  The ambiance is dark and intimate, rustic yet modern, just like the discrete storefront outside.$225 including taxes (Above courses, three wines + Giant Caesar, dozen oysters, espresso).  To use the rude vile American saying, it was so totally HELLA worth it, dude.

I've eaten here before and we loved it, however this experience was completely different. We had a reservation for 8:45, and when we showed up at 8:47 were told that our table had been given up to another group because we were late and they hadn't been able to reach us. We honestly thought she was joking because it seemed so ridiculous. Apparently we had one digit  wrong in our phone number and because we didn't call to say we'd be late, and "15 groups hadn't shown up all night" they decided to give our table away. The hostess was dismissive and unapologetic and blamed us for being late. We are really easy going and reasonable people but it was so frustrating and upsetting to be treated so poorly. We know the food is good from previous experience  but the service was really really disappointing.

The service and the food was great. The waitress really helped explain the menu.Their speciality is sea food, so try ordering at-least one dish. I had the big eye tuna appetizer and it was delicious with the right seasoning.The portions doesn't do much justice for the price, but delicious none the less.My only issue was with the lobster poutine. I am no poutine expert but I felt the fries were  quite burned and was a little sparse on the gravy.Ambience:5/5 Food: 4/5Service: 4/5

This was our 2nd visit to Garde Manger. Only this time it was extra special. Not only was Mr. Hughes present, but he was gracious enough to help me propose to my girlfriend. I sincerely thank the staff and Chuck for this momentous event. Truly a highlight in our lives and we will forever remember the occasion. Aside from the proposal, the food and service was just as perfect! The only place in Montreal to get the best Oysters.Thank you Chuck!!!

NOT WHAT THEY USED TO BE!  We havent been there in about a 1.5 and decided since we used to go there frequenty- we would go back w/ my Dad in town.  Walked in, the decor and the ambiance went from what used to be cool, chic, edgy- to lame calm restaurant.  The waiter had no personality- I asked him "Is the place still as good as it used to be?" his resonse -walked away. OK.Now onto the food...Ordered oysters and another appetizer (lobster poutine which was DELISH) and 2 main dishes.  They served us everything together! REALLY?! What happened to apps come first then dinner? Best part was we had a variety of oysters- the ones from BC ended up being super fishy. The waiter replied " Oh yes i HATE those too".  So why not tell us that before we ordered them?! Thanks a lot for nothing! The gnocchi in a meat sauce was absolutly disgusting- it was like chineese beef dish sauce and a few random tiny gnocci floating around.  Sad to say if your a real foodie like we are- who go out multiple times a week..avoid this place.Came home and ordered a pizza!  Sorry Chuck- shame.

4.5/5 rounded up because I loved their tunes.The experience at Garde Manger was close to perfect, and as many previous reviewers have noted, the setting is wonderful. Our waitress was more than attentive, as were the busboys and even bartender. Our party of 4 shared 3 appetizers; oysters, octopus with fingerling potatoes and chorizo, and lobster poutine. The 3 varieties of oysters were all delicious, the octopus a little too seared for my liking, but the poutine is something that grows on you I find. The first bite might be a little confusing to the palate but I was going back for more. For mains we had; short-ribs with Stilton cheese, 2 had the rock shrimp risotto, and I had the seared scallops with potato and brussel sprouts. I tried the risotto, which was a little too al dente for me but delicious, and the scallops were so fresh and the whole dish was perfection.We didn't really have room for dessert, and two people had some of their special drinks (home-made Five Alive with gin, and a virgin classic Bloody Cesar). Next time I think we might try all apps so that we can try even more.

Small menu with a good variety.  Not too heavy and surprisingly delicate presentation.  We had the Octopus and Jerusalem artichoke appetizers, both went over very well.  Scallops and Shorts ribs as mains, again very popular.  The house smores had great flavour but the sticky factor of the marshmellows was off the charts and made the dessert very difficult to eat!

Pretentious.. the only good thing I can say about this restaurant is that the staff and service was great!! Food was OK, but WAY over priced... Oh and put a sign up.. this restaurant is not good enough to think that they don't need a sign..
Delicious place for food. Nice ambience. Book far in advance. Great service. Check out the cocktail - it comes with crab legs!

Disclaimer: I have watched Chuck Hughes and wanted to try one of his restaurants. I take celebrity chef restaurants with a grain of salt and I go in with low expectations. Before I went I checked online if any reservations were available. No reservations were available so I took a risk and headed down.  To make sure I would have a chance to get in, I went right when they opened at 5:30. Much to my surprise, during the approximately two hours I was there, the restaurant wasn't full. What is up with there being no reservations available?  When I eat at "fine" dining establishments I like to order a little at a time. I don't have my entire meal planned out as I don't know how filling each course will be. Maybe after the first course I'll find the food isn't good and I will want to leave.  I started doing that and the person who served me said, "You will get better service if you order all of your food at once."  What?I've never heard that in my life. It smacked of get 'em in and get 'em out. I left after the first course. I did, however, try the house-made smoked salmon. That was delicious.

We were told this was a must when visiting, so decided to go on our last night in town. The location is hard to find, with no signage really on the outside. However, I think that's on purpose as the atmosphere is very unpretentious. You get the feeling its all about the food, though the setting is very charming with an old world feel. The food was amazing. The waitress did a great job suggesting a wine to pair with my meal, and everything was spot on.

Amazing food and service. Alexandro was a fun and informative server. Seafood tower was great. Lobster poutine was delish. Jerk crab was expensive but good. Worth visiting. It's loud but the music is great.

Alexandro was an excellent server. Lobster poutine, seafood platter & arctic char was perfect. It is a noisier atmosphere so it was a lot of fun. Make sure to make reservations. Least favourite was sparerib dish; it was too dry.

The food is very delicate. It's quite packed even on Thursday night at 6 pm. We ended up sitting in the bar area. All staffs were very friendly and introduced the dishes clearly. The menu changes periodically and posts on the wall. We were talked into ordering duck, scallops, and a starter. The scallops were super fresh and the chef cooked so well to keep them crispy outside but extremely tender inside, and so as the duck. They were all seasoned excellently! Portions were kind of very small. We ended up ordering another entree: fresh code, which was also very delicious. Even pricey, I enjoyed it a lot.

What a delicious experience! The veal tartar with foie mousse was my favorite. You can't go wrong with that. And they didn't. The kicker was the maple toast. The combination of tartar, foie mousse on the toast...delish. Effing delish. Well-flavored and a nice portion. The braised beef tortellini was done well but I wasn't a fan of the al dente pasta. But that's just preference. The spot prawns were great, no shell or head, and very soft. I was expecting a bit firmer but was pleasantly surprised. Wish they cut the baby fennel but still good. I had the striped bass, which was perfectly cooked. Moist and tender on the inside and crispy on the outside. The skin was a little salty but I thought it went well with the rest of the dish, which included spatzle, truffles and a lobster beurre blanc. Omg, so good. Dessert was a strawberry meringue. I'm sure it's called something else and I've butchered it but still delicious! The cake part seemed undercooked and am not sure if that's how it was supposed to be. But again, great flavors and very good portions. Great wine selections. A few more to add to my collection. I left satisfied. Not overly stuffed and hating myself. Great service, as well. Our waitress was very nice and helpful. The rest of the staff was also very attentive. We were fairly early so could be because there weren't a lot of customers as of yet. But great experience. I'd definitely go again. And to Chuck Hughes's other restaurant.

Garde Manger is one of the most talked about restaurants in Montreal, and with lots of hype comes high expectations. Service and atmosphere were very good. The restaurant is very cozy, tucked away just off St Paul. I split the famous lobster poutine with my friend as an appetizer and had the beef short rib for my main, as recommended by a friend. The food was very good but it was not out of this world considering all the hype. I would definitely return to this fun venue in future.

Brilliant.  An all around great dining expereince.Lobster Poutine and Octopus with Chorizo were our apps. Mains were braised short ribs and lobster roll with match stick frites.Mini ice cream sandwiches and s'mores cake was the perfect way to round out the meal

David the trifecta who looks like David Beckham,Tom Cruise and Bradley Cooper gave me the best service I have ever experienced. Definitely ask to sit at his back bar. Make sure to ask for the secret one scallop dish! Lovely ambience and great people!!!

The Lobster Poutine was pretty good. The fries were very fresh and the gravy light tasting. Definitely worth the try. The Rock Shrimp Risotto was very tasty....finished with lemon zest. Enjoyable experience.

Tried the scallops and the famous lobster poutine. The scallops was "so so" but my wife liked it. However I would definitely come back for the poutine. It's way better than any poutine at La Banquise. This guy takes poutine to another level!

first things first: make a reservation! I read reviews and made a reservation in advance and it really helped. It is a smaller restaurant but everyone diner is well taken care of so they have to restrict the number of customers.I have been watching Chuck Hughes on tv for years and love his shows and recipes so when I was visiting Montreal, naturally I had to eat at one of his restaurants. The food was beyond what I had imagined! I got the braised rib and it was the best braised rib I have ever had in my life! My boyfriend had a yummy crusty fish on top of crispy pasta. For dessert, I had the ice cream sandwich with caramel sauce and my boyfriend got the boozy affogato. Both incredible! We had such a lovely waiter who was really knowledgeable and personable. Excellent service. He even gave us a cute little garde manger souvenir post card.
So delicious the first night, we went back the next night! The razor clams and Atlantic char are outstanding! The service impeccably friendly and efficient. Next time I'm in Montreal, I will return.

Went here with three other people. Collectively, we kept ordering until we tried more than half of what was listed on the blackboard that day, including braised rabbit risotto, and cornish hens stuffed with foie gras, as well as a giant seafood platter that came served in a trough. My only complaint was that the rabbit we ordered was a little salty. Other than that, everything was amazing.Note: We booked seats farrrr in advance and recommend you do the same!
Love the seafood platter, lobster poutine & jerk crabs (so spicy that I cried lol) perfectly pear with a pilsner!

Came here on a business dinner. It did not disappoint. The food was fantastic, and the waiter was very friendly and knowledgable.  Rather than individual dinners for each person, he instead arranged for us to have various dishes brought out so we could all enjoy them family style. In this way we were able to try a wide selection of dishes. They were all amazing.In the summer I'm planning a personal trip to Montreal, and this will be one of my stops again.

Garde manger is a foodie dream for this girl! First visit, chuck was expediting and took a minute to chat and pose for a pic. Love him, he looks chubby on tv but in person he's skinny! Anyhoo, lets talk turkey. Well, oysters first. They have multiple varieties available, the servers know how each oyster is different than the other, and the condiments are top-notch: finely grated fresh horseradish, delicious mignonette and lovely lemon. Ok, chuck didn't make the lemons but the oyster platter was unbelievably good! If you like oysters in a just a little bit, you love these, and if you like oysters, you will be in oyster heaven. If you've never tried them before, order just one! Give it a try! The braised short ribs are delicious. Lobster poutine, meh. I love lobster, but I like it naked and cold not all saucy and hot. But if you like lobster, fries and cheese goodness, you will love this dish. Best fries ever, the curd cheese was perfect. What strikes me as profound, is that the side dishes at this restaurant are usually so well prepared and delicious, I tend to eat the veggies before getting to the meat! The best Swiss chard ever, the most delicious roasted cauliflower! If you love cocktails, you will love this place! Try their drink of the day, and/or have the special bloody Ceasar. I like spicy food, but find when you ask for no or less spice, it works better in this drink with a huge snowcrab claw as a stir stick! Love the food, love chuck. Pants are tight when you leave here, so plan to take a walk!

Came here based on VERY STRONG recs and it did not disappoint! We didn't have reservations, but came right when they opened. Luckily, they let us have a table for 1.5 hrs since there was a reservation coming in then. We started with the lobster poutine - the sauce was delicious and there was SO MUCH lobster on that dish! More than I expected! We also had the braised short rib which was SO TENDER and FLAVORFUL! It was such a filling dish and the sides were also surprisingly tasty. Halfway thru our meal I saw another table order a seafood app and wanted some oysters. So, we ordered some of that too! The oysters were fresh and nicely shucked... delicious! I also saw someone order a bloody mary with the large crab leg. Looks interesting... but not something I'm into.Since it's a pretty intimate place we started chatting with a couple from the table next to ours and found that they were from NY! It was a nice that we enjoyed our meal AND made new friends! It was a great experience and I highly recommend it!

Apps were great, I could say that the lobster poutine was really great. The tomato salad was exceptional as well, with its fresh ricotta cheese and bright vinaigrette. The mains weren't anything to go out of your way for. We both had fish, the artic char I had was approximately 6 ounces which was fine but the dish was 36 dollars and there was one piece on top of the other making the bottom piece of fish soggy, why bother crisping the skin. The other fish we got was the stripped bass which was very fishy. The Bloody Mary was really tasty, nice and spicy. The dessert, peach cobbler, was boring and flat. I wouldn't go back but it's worth checking out. It seemed like a tourist trap for people looking for a celebrity chef experience, myself included. I could imagine that most of the individuals who went we like myself, from out of town.

This is a very nice restaurant and the service is very friendly. But if seafood is not your thing, skip it. I should have just let my friends go without me. They try to be accommodating but it's pretty impossible. My friends wanted to do the chef's menu so you get what the kitchen wants to prepare. It was all nice looking, just so nothing for me. I ate a lot of bread and drank wine. For five people we paid almost $900 including tip. I left hungry though.

What a wonderful evening...from the food...to the ambience...to the service it hit everything we could have wanted. Our waiter made wonderful suggestions throughout our meal...drinks...cocktails....food.courses...we love Montreal and we are big fans of Mr. Chuck Hughes. This was as good if not better than Le Bremner....it is not inexpensive but worth every penny. Side bar: The famous lobster poutine has been discontinued.

Great atmosphere! I loved the music (was singing along the whole time)! Although I'm not a big fan of seafood, I managed to find myself eating here!The waitress was incredibly nice and answered all our questions and suggested great dishes. Personally, I wasn't a big fan of the menus written on a board and put up on the wall.. just because it felt awkward having to look over another table to try and read it! I'm pretty sure the people on the table didn't enjoy that either haha! But the waitress did take the time to go over the menu for us and she knew everything pretty much by heart -Thumbs up!We ordered and shared the lobster poutine, as the waitress recommended, as our appetizer! By the time we finished it, we were already quite full! They also bring you some bread and cheese as soon as you sit down!I ordered the steak which was cooked to medium-rare (and no you can't choose how well you want it cooked -didn't like that). It came with some salad on the side. Overall, wasn't that fulfilling, unfortunately. Be sure to make a reservation ahead of time if you want to find a place to sit. (Rumour alert) They apparently take their reservation seriously that they won't even cancel it or make room for a celebrity who doesn't have a reservation.

We had beef carpaccio, mozzarella - zucchini - lobster, and a duck magret/confit main with a fabulous Bergerac Bordeaux.. The food was delicious and the service was great.. A wonderful culinary experience.. We definitely recommend the place!

I had made a reservation on the DINR app and the reservation said 5:30-9:30, which I thought meant you can go anytime in between those times. When I had arrived at the restaurant at 7pm they proceedto tell me that my reservation was at 5:30 and I had missed it. They said there was a glitch on the DINR app, so the time was wrong. They told me that they tried to call me, but the thing is I'm visiting from New York so I don't have any cell phone service. I can only use Internet while connected to wifi, or text. They did not attempt to text me or email me, they should know that there are many travelers from outside the country that may not be reached through calling! Nobody even apologized to me. This completely ruined my last night in Montreal. It was 7pm and I had already taken a cab to the area and I was left with no reservations. And if anybody knows me I plan everything ahead of time so I hate when my plans get ruined like this. And it is hard to get a table at some of the high rated restaurants in the city. Thanks a lot for ruining my last meal in Montreal. I am beyond angry about this! They didn't even try to resolve the situation in any way. OH and to top it off they emailed me saying my credit card would be charged. Unbelievable

What a disappointment!  I was looking forward to trying this restaurant, as Chef Hughes is so well reviewed.  The meal was an overwhelming disappointment.  The illegible hand-scribbled menu on Saturday night had nothing but seafood and fish, except for a hanger steak and pork chops.  So, we ordered the pork and the hanger steak.  They were both horrible.  The steak was very tough and the fibers in the meat were too strong and too "chewy".  The pork chop was even tougher and very undercooked.  The pork chop was just too big - this probably explains why it was so tough and so undercooked.I will not go back.

Went here for drinks, because the line at Santos across the street was huge! It was a lot of fun the crowd was young, and DJ was playing some old school Hip Hop, songs most people know but you never hear! Drinks were good had 20 year old Porto at 25$ a glass, not something you find everywhere. I'll def go back for dinner!

Chucks day off. Sara: 3/5Suk: 4/5We felt lucky to get into Garde Manger when we called the Sunday morning to ask about reservations that evening and were told, yes, please come at 7:15pm.  We felt less lucky when we showed up at 7:15pm and were told by the hostess, we will be with you in a minute.  That minute morphed into 30 minutes, with nowhere to sit, no offer of water or a beverage, no preview of the menu and no acknowledgement of our presence beyond the first, "hello, do you have a reservation, we will be with you in a minute".   I am an impatient person and the only reason we stuck around that long is because Montreal had an amazing video series of it's history projected against different buildings around old Montreal which we viewed to kill the time.  That, and Suk really wanted to eat here. I personally would have been ready to leave 15 minutes in.  We were eventually ushered in and seated at the back bar.  Once we were there, we ordered oysters, jerk crab and the braised short ribs.  If you have read any of my previous reviews you know I do not review oysters unless they are off - oysters are oysters and these oysters were great.  Thank you ocean and thank you fishermen.    No need to thank a particular restaurant for serving the fruits of other people's labour.  The jerk crab was amazeballs.   Yum yum yum!  What's that? This isn't your own homemade marinade? Maybe Graces? As in available at most grocery stores across the country?  So now, one dish which is actually from CH, short ribs!   Tough yet fatty and little seasoning. We left half of it because it was mostly fat.   Fantastic service

When I watched episodes of "Chuck's Day Off", I always thought it would've so cool to eat at his restaurant.  When I realized I was coming to Montreal, I thought wouldn't it be cool to eat at that restaurant--but didn't remember the name or Chuck's last name.  Also, I thought--"there's no way it's close to where we're staying..."Then we took a walking tour of the "Tastes of Old Montreal".  During the tour, our guide points out the completely unnoticeable Le Garde Manger, and says it is one of the best restaurants in the city, owned by Chef Chuck Hughes.  Yay!!!  We managed to get a reservation, and were rewarded with great ambiance, fun interaction with a cool, informed and engaging staff, and we got some really great food.  Our meal started with a delightful goat cheese board paired with crisp, light flatbread.  Then I got the striped sea bass and my husband got the grilled scallops.  Both entrees were just as delicious as expected.  For dessert we shared the ice cream sandwiches with caramel dipping sauce, and I'm only a little embarrassed to say I cleaned our plate.The meal was tasty, fun and memorable.  Perfect for a vacation visit!!

My colleague and I went here during a business trip to Montreal last week.  Since we arrived late (9:30pm) we had no trouble getting a spot but in the end we decided to get a seat at the bar and eat there.We had the best bartender/waiter serve us...His name is Sam and I got the best service I have ever had in a restaurant from us.  He was very knowledgeable about the menu and we took him up on a lot of his advice for us on the food and the wine.We had the seafood platter, the tuna tartare and a pan fried arctic char and all three dishes were unbelievably delicious and fresh.  Sam also introduced us to a wicked shot ("hot shot") which was layered maple whiskey with hot espresso on top.  I am definitely coming back here the next time I'm in Montreal.

It seems like everyone that adores Garde-Manger is a tourist. We came here for dinner and even though we had a reservation, we were seated in the worst spot possible: in front of a huge pole so that the server could barely see us or our usually empty glasses. The lobster poutine had maybe 4 little pieces of lobster, pretty sure that it wasn't quite how Chuck made it on the Iron Chef ;) The seafood platter was nothing to write home about: the oysters were 'meh', the shrimp was equally 'meh' but the crab was pretty decent. Our main dishes were equally forgettable: my scallops tasted like half a salt shaker was emptied into the sauce. Also, because of said pole in front of us, the server miscalculated refilling my dates glass and spilled a fairly large amount of expensive red wine all over him; that was a nice touch (didn't even get a free dessert out of that catastrophe).I do however quite like the atmosphere, the kick ass chandelier, stone walls, central location and the variety of music though, so see, it's not all negative.

Over....rated.  The ambiance of the restaurant is great, the menu is written up on the chalkboard, and our meal started off fantastically with our appetizer.  Unfortunately the Lobster Poutine is totally over hyped.  First and foremost, the amount of lobster on the poutine was pretty pathetic consisting only of two large pieces of claw.  The flavor of the gravy was bland as could be.  Since it seems every restaurant has their version of poutine, I would have expected this famous chef to kick it up a notch in terms of creativity.  Simply throwing lobster on a dish to make it "elegant" or command the ridiculous price for this dish is simply laziness.  To be honest during the entire trip, the best poutine I had was at Le Roy Jucep and it would put Garde Manger's version to shame.

This review is for the lobster poutine only.Service and Ambiance:   * We visited this place just for the poutine.  It was late, so I liked the dark, Seattle bar-like (or American), energetic feel of this place.  They were playing Bob Marley too, so I was nostalgic and feeling the love.    * They were busy and closing the kitchen. But they still agreed to make us their famous lobster poutine, which was awesome.Poutine   * When in Montreal, aside from the French cuisine, you have to go to Schwartz for smoked meat and of course, you gotta try the poutine.   It is a common Canadian dish, originating in Quebec in 1950's, made with french fries, topped with a light brown gravy-like sauce and cheese curds.  We had the lobster poutine and it was delicious (compared with others I tried in Montreal).  It had big pieces of lobster and a really flavorful gravy.  I wanted to try the foie gras poutine at Au Pied du Cuchon when I dined there next day, but too much of a good thing can be detrimental to ones health. My body may never forgive me for the abuse and there were other interesting and healthier dishes to sample. Summary:Definitely worth a try, if you are in Old Montreal, if you like lobster, and if you are not too concern with getting fat from the delicious gravy and curds, along with the deep fried potatoes.  It's so good but so bad.  If you are in Seattle, my first and repeating poutine experience was at Smith.  Best spare rib poutine ever! yumm.A clarification to my comments about poutines above.    * Personally, I feel potatoes get a bad rap. No potato in its natural state is bad for us, but rather we make it bad because of how we eat it (e.g., deep fry) or when we decide to eat it (e.g., late night). A potato is a starch and it is made up of simple carbohydrates. Starch has a place in our diet.  Like everything we consume, moderation is key.     * With respect to potatoes, when our body takes in these quickly-absorbing carbohydrates we are forced to use them as energy right away or store them in fat. Unless we are headed to the gym after we eat or consume them after exercise, we are more likely to gain weight from these kinds of potatoes.  When we continually consume quickly absorbing carbohydrates, the high conversion of sugar causes a surge in insulin production. When we continually spike our insulin, we develop a resistance to insulin that has been linked to a higher risk of diabetes and heart disease.

Where do I begin? If you can find it, eat here! Ask for Alessandro, eat what he recommends, drink what he suggests, you'll enjoy every minute. Or, do it on your own (pick from the ambitious and versatile menu on the chalk board behind [1/2] you), either way you'll end up very, very happy. The food is incredible, the atmosphere (and service) easily matched the high expectations we had for this place. This is a dining EXPERIENCE. Going back tomorrow and Thursday.

This is the quintessential Montreal dinner spot - cozy, delicious food and so welcoming on a cold winter's eve. Having an every-changing chalkboard-only menu is a bold move, but it is very clear that Chuck Hughes knows what's up.We had the spaghetti squash with buffalo mozzarella, sultanas and pistachios, along with the lamb meatballs to start. This combo easy takes the cake compared to any version of its more traditional counterpart, good ol' spaghetti and meatballs. The spaghetti squash was cooked perfectly (no broken or soggy strands here), and when the melted mozzarella oozed into it, it was pure butter. The lamb meatballs were deliciously savory, and were cut with a bit of sharp feta, also fantastic.For our main, we shared the duck with beets and butternut squash. The duck was succulent and juicy and the beets and squash were roasted perfectly, with a bit of crisp on the outside, but melt in your mouth mash on the inside. Again, amazing.Dessert didn't disappoint - salted caramel profiteroles. Despite having no chocolate (my usual and often only dessert selection), these little treasures were very worth it. Good americano to wash it down, too.Service was warm and informative.

Just got back from a business trip and this place won my heart.  My co-workers and I enjoy good food and drinks, so we will always find anew places to go to on our travels... this place was SO good, we ate here two nights in a row!  We tried different entrees on each occasions and I can honestly say that every item we ate was equally as good!  BUT if I have to list out my favorites it would be:* Lobster Poutine ( AMAZING!)* ShortRib* Skate wing Fish* Cheesecake mousse with Dulce de LecheWe had the lovely waitress, Ada ( might be wrong spelling) both nights and she made our experience even better.  I can't say enough good things about this restaurant.  I wish there was one in California so I could back again!

We came here because of a friend's recommendation, not because we knew anything about the celebrity chef. Maybe it was that ignorance that prompted us to boldly call the restaurant at 8 on a Saturday night to see if they had space for 2 (they did!)The restaurant is lovely, and the neighborhood is gorgeous. I agree that it's pretentious that they don't have a sign, but whatever, we found it. My partner got the foie gras and the lobster special and proclaimed it delicious; I had mixed greens and Steak Diane... the sauce was wonderful. We had great service at the bar, it was all very convivial and warm... a very nice experience.

I'm a Montrealer who's eaten at many of the city's top restaurants over the years. But for some reason, I never got to Garde Manger. I tried, on occasion to make a reservation online but it was always booked months in advance. I finally got a reservation for this past Friday. We arrived a bit early and we're seated in the back part of the restaurant right away. I was surprised to see such limited choice on the blackboard menu, which, by the way was practically impossible to read from where we were sitting. In either case, no single appetizer or entre jumped out at us. So we went with the chef's menu to get a taste of everything. This came with a variety shellfish including shrimps, lobster, oysters plus smoked arctic char and albacore tuna tartar. The char and tartar were excellent. The rest of the seafood platter was fine...how hard is it to screw up boiled shrimp and lobster? At $100 per person, I was expecting to be wow'd in the subsequent courses. I wasn't. Not saying it wasn't good but I expected more, especially given Garde Manger and chef Hughe's reputation. Second course included a birri tomato salad with focaccia cheese, a spicy zucchini salad with a deep fried zucchini with cheese and finally some beef carpaccio. It was good but didn't blow me away. The final course included scallops with pork belly and corn, pork tenderloin with jalapeño grits and spaetzle with mushrooms and onions. The pork and scallops were very good and I didn't really care for the spaetzle.Overall, I would say it was OK but nothing to rave about. Honestly, I don't understand the fuss over this place. This is comfort food. It's also a laid back place with patrons in t-shirts, shorts and flip-flops. I was expecting a more refined and sophisticated culinary experience. Frankly, I expect more for $350 (2 people including 2 cocktails and a glass of wine each). The waitress was very nice and knowledgeable. Now that I've experienced Garde Manger, I won't be sorry if I don't go back for a while. I think there are plenty of other restaurants in Montreal that can offer superior, more refined food for the same money.

The Wikipedia entry for "overrated" should feature a photo of this place.  The stench of arrogance coming from the staff could maybe be tolerated if the food were better than the average old port tourist trap.  This place no longer really sees the light of day on any credible top lists in Montreal, and there's a reason why.  I can't endorse this restaurant for anything other than a cozy interior, which is why I give it a second star.

This restaurant was featured on a food network show, and my family took note since we were going to Montreal. It was a disappointment. First off, the spicy strawberry ginger lemonade that was recommended to us by our server was so watered down it was simply a $5 glass of water. The appetizer we chose was pasta based; the pasta was mushy on the outside, hard on the inside, but the sauce was very good. The entrees were decent, but my mother-in-law's dish was not hot, it was actually quite cool. The side dish of vegetables we ordered was not the best; in fact, all four of us felt it upset our stomaches. The one thing we all enjoyed unequivocally was dessert; our server recommended the coffee cake and it was divine. All in all, while the service was great, we won't be back.

The bartender Sam was awesome, made great cocktails out off menu and great service.   But food wasn't so impressive. Smoky salmon tartar with black rice was way too salt, and the famous lobster poutin more like sautéed Lobster on bunch of over fried french fries.. not impressive at all.

Wonderful from beginning to end. We started with cocktails and lobster poutine. I ordered the duck and my partner ordered the pork. Both were absolutely wonderful. The meats were both moist and full of flavor. We ended our night with a blackberry and pistachio dessert that made me want to order four more.

We were in town only for a few days and so we weren't able to get a reservation but I should have called to check!  In any case we were walking by after dinner and stopped there for drinks at the bar.  We were surprised to see the place pretty empty.  Oh well... The service was impeccable and the drink specials and selection heavenly!  Not a full bar I think but they had some real beauties (ie Japanese whisky and some other liquors that I rarely see but wish I had a higher alcohol tolerance to try them all).  The music selection was awesome as well (sounded like my playlist between a few late 80s songs with more recent ones) and set at the right volume so you can hum along but still hold a conversation.  We didn't eat but the food around us looked amazing and our drinks were amazing!
What a place. The service is amazing. Food is the best. A must stop in Montreal. The food was the best I had in Montreal. The atmosphere is amazing

I had really high expectations going to Chuck Hughes' restaurant. It was one of the coolest experiences vibe-wise that I've experienced at a restaurant. The wine, company, and service was excellent. The reviews from diners in our party ranged were generally good. The oyster + scallops first course looked amazing, as well as the signature lobster poutine.However, I would certainly not recommend Garde-Manger for vegetarians. The only veggie choice listed on the chalkboard was a beet and cabbage appetizer, and the waiter recommended the veggie risotto. Instead of a decadent and luscious risotto, I was presented with an overly salty risotto that was utterly forgettable. The lack of creativity here was disappointing.Which is a shame. The wine, conversation, ambiance, and music were all excellent. But my meal was a disappointment and messing up on something so basic as seasoning is never a good thing.

Let me start by saying that my wife and I drove from New York City to eat at this restaurant, which certainly creates great expectations! My wife is a big fan of Chuck Hughes and his shows so she was hoping that he was in the kitchen, but he was not that night. We were seated immediately at the time of our reservation in a really quiet table in the back room. Our server was very friendly and a total pro, as were all of the staff that night. Every morsel of food we had that great night from the beef carpaccio to the scallops was totally amazing! All I can say is that it was well worth the trip- even from New York City!!!!! The only things that would have been the topper was if Chuck was there!!! Maybe next time!!!!

The last stop on my Food Day in Montreal was Garde Manger and I definitely made the right choice. I was dining alone so I sat at the bar where the absolutely adorable bartender offered to make me an Old Fashioned instead of the Basil Hayden's, neat that I had ordered. It was perfect! I ordered the lobster poutine which came out fairly quickly. The huge chunks of lobster claw were sweet, the cheese curds were gooey and the gravy was savory. The fries were fresh and seasoned perfectly. Garde Manger was the highlight of my trip...I walked past it twice because it's not clearly marked. Make sure you're watching out for it!

Ate here last night and had a mixed experience. Atmosphere and service is good. Dishes are hit and miss:Seafood platter of oysters & cold smoked salmon: greatBeet salad w/ apple, dill and buttermilk dressing: very niceLobster poutine: very salty and not much lobster (19$)Beef cheek gnocchi: too salty, greasy and some odd Asian flavors mixed in  (the biggest looser of the night.) Venison served rare: delicious.

Best Restaurant in the World. My husband and I have dined at iconic and well known establishments around the world, and this is by far the best restaurant we've been to. We were there on Wednesday, March, 14th, and David took care of us. We had the chef's menu and we were surprised and delighted with every dish that came out. My husband doesn't like certain sea foods but that night he tried it and loved it-- This was all due to the freshness and preparation of the food. The oysters were sweet and delicate. There was not even a hint of any fishy-ness in any of the sea food and fish we had. We loved the variety in the seafood platter. Everything we had was absolutely delicious and layered with different flavours, and nice lingering tastes. The texture of the BC Tuna was so tender, it melted in your mouth. The beef carpaccio had different bursts of flavour and textures and mini potato chips on top which gave it a little salty crunch. We had the salad that had an amazing crispness and thickness; it was both satisfying and refreshing and somehow the Gorgonzola in it was buttery, and not at all overpowering. We also had the juicy pork shank, and even the carrots were nicely seasoned. Each component of each dish was flavourful. The staff was great. We liked the atmosphere; it was very cozy with the fireplaces and lighting.  It was a good loud, with people talking and laughing, which made it feel even cozier because everyone was enjoying drinking and eating so much, that they were oblivious to the fact that it was a cold and snowy work-night. David asked us if we're celebrating anything and we then came out with peanut butter profiteroles and the fireworks for my husband's birthday. Before we left someone came by and asked how everything was, and we held our full bellies and said "Excellent" and  "Perfect". We were also pleasantly surprised with the bill.  We thought the bill would be around $500, and it only turned out to be $230 for copious amounts of delectable food. We are planning a trip to Montreal this summer just to return to Garde Manger.  We've been telling our friends about it and we already have two other couples planning a trip to Montreal just to go to Garde Manger.

A definite must for those in the area.  The service was good, drinks better, food incredible.Had the 2 special cocktails for the night.  There was a sweet and refreshing pear and maple syrup cocktail w/ vodka as the base.  The other was basically a giant bloody mary garnished w/ beef jerky covered in horseradish sauce and pickles.  Not really a bloody mary fan, but the tomato juice wasn't overpowering and it wasn't too salty, so I didn't mind helping finish it off.  The beef jerky garnish didn't really do much for me, really salty, but I guess in a place like this, you can't just be serving up the standard bloody mary that the plebians drink.Started off with the Octopus, fingerlings, creme fraiche and chorizo.  The octopus was prepared soft and tender, not the usually chewiness you associate with it.  The creme fraiche added the slightest hint of sweetness to the dish.  A few celery leaves balanced out the experience.The main course was a seafood risotto and scallops w/ bacon, buttercup squash, and black truffle.The shrimp was plump and tender, with the risotto being cooked al dente.  The fried calimari that topped it off was amazing.  So light and flavorful.Scallops were cooked perfectly, which is a rarity.  You usually either get something that's cook too much or too little, which ends up being too chewy or raw and ruins the dish, but not here.Capped off the night with a couple desserts, affogato w/ grand marnier and financier topped off w/ pistachio ice cream.  I'm not gonna even bother w/ a description, it was good.Bottom line, you can't go wrong.  The food, drinks, service, ambiance, were al great.

Such an awesome place. The service, atmosphere and food were all amazing. They were very accommodating with my food allergies (gluten and dairy), I had lots of options to pick from. I would highly recommend making this a stop on your list when you visit Montreal.

From the moment we were seated, our lovely waitress answered our questions and was more than happy to make recommendations when (as usual) I couldn't make up my mind over 2-3 options. Her recommendations were spot on, including the bottle of red wine that my friend and I ordered. Everything just seemed delicious and worth trying! However, life isn't always that fair, SO...For the appetizers, we shared a small lobster poutine and lentil bruschetta. I would wholeheartedly suggest the bruschetta. It was fantastic and exploding with flavour! I could have never imagined it coming together as perfectly as it did. On the other hand, I had big expectations of the lobster poutine. Unfortunately it didn't quite hit the spot, as I didn't find a single chunk of lobster in my dish... The fries tasted great, so did the lobster gravy, but I did want some lobster in my lobster-poutine. C'est tout.For the mains, we ordered the walleye fish in bonito broth with speck and egg pasta, and the pork chops over eggplant and kale. While the walleye fish was good, it was a little on the salty side. However, my pork chops were mind blowing. I was skeptical, as I often find them to be overcooked and dry, but WOW... They were moist, tender, and flavorful, that's all I can begin to even say about them.Honestly, I was surprised I could even get a reservation here just a day before, but it worked. Maybe because it was in the middle of the week at a late time, but no matter what, this place is constantly on the go and so bangin'. Check it out, no matter how long the wait may be!

I came in fully ready to be disappointed considering the level of hype involved, but I was glad to be proven wrong. Nice atmosphere, friendly and very knowledgeable staff, an interesting menu and overall great food (I had the jerk crab and ribs). I'd probably eat here again eventually if I didn't have to book a reservation a month in advance, but I can't really blame them for their popularity.

I have been hoping to try Chuck's place for years and finally did this trip. It was great, really it was.  Would I go back?  Probably not.  The food was very good, the service even better.  We had the 6:30 seating which was nice because I understand it gets a bit loud for the 10 seating. We found the music great and although getting louder as time went on it was excellent. Was Chuck there;sadly not but the waitress was a wealth of information. Food:  Lobster poutine my friend had, she said was good but not great.  I had the best ever Caesar which turned out to be an appetizer in itself with crab (and it was fresh) and horseradish. My husband had beef ragout and he loved it.  Overall very good near excellent. I wonder if the hype doesn't pull it down somewhat.  Loved finally getting there and having the experience.

This was our favorite restaurant during a recent visit to Montreal.  Yes, we had the lobster poutine, and it was wonderful.  The service was great and the restaurant had a fun, lively vibe. Reservations are essential, so the restaurant was packed, and it is expensive (hence the four, rather than five, stars).  I'd certainly make this a "must" for my next trip to Montreal.

Incredible food and service! We opted for the chef's tasting menu and recommend this if you want to try several menu items. For $60 pp we received a platter of 15 oysters and smoked salmon, 5 appetizers, and 4 entrees split amongst 5 people. Portion sizes were generous! We took leftovers home to enjoy the next day! Will definitely come back here the next time we're in Montreal!

My wife and I went to Garde Manger last Friday night and had one of the most memorable and enjoyable dining experiences of our lives!  We sat at the bar and our bartender/server Sam took care of everything for us -- we gave him a little direction about what types of food we liked and he took it from there...and proceeded to dazzle us with three amazing courses, plus dessert and drinks.  We had such a great time and highly recommend this restaurant to anyone who is in Montreal.

Chuck's team has nicely represented Garde-Manger on the gastropub scene with it's purple light shining on old Montreal.Menu is nicely elevated with a few seasonal dish that may come and go, revolving around steady classics and all executed with a twist. The short ribs, making the podium hands down for the meat team sharing a close spot with the shelfish "box" on the food-appeal photo finish. Any appetizers with foie gras is a must indulge almost to a point where you want to skip dessert and grab some more! Too bad some of us are blessed with shelfish allergies... The lobster poutine looks addictive!Wine list is elaborated, steap in price but will complement any orders.Staff is knowledgeable, very attentive and making the dinning experience enjoyeable. No need to mention service is near spotless.Good for business type dinners, not so good for a cheap date. Decor and music brings a pefect ambiance to this out of the box experience.Online reservation days in advance is a must as walk-in patrons may get welcome another evening. Expect to spend 2h indulging.
Ambience, service and food was top Knotch! Duck was amazing, as was the lobster poutine and wine selection!Thanks for a wonderful evening!

Three of us walked in without a reservation at 7:00 on a Friday night. They said we could have the best table in house if we had to returned by 9. Done. We sat right next to the open window on a beautiful night. It's a cozy spot -- full of Old Montreal character. Service was great. We had wine and long island iced teas. The seafood platter (yum), the lobster poutine (my compatriots loved, I thought was just okay) and the sardine salad (delicious). All in all a great night in Old Montreal.
Had a great experience, the background music and service was great. Had the Arctic Chard with egg plant was wonderful. Very enjoyable night out.

Excellent service and ambiance.  Was here for dinner two nights ago and had a great time.  We had the seafood platter (half lobster tail, oysters and razor clams), lobster poutine (their signature dish) and the scallop entree.  The apps were amazing - but scallop entree was just so so.  Wasnt a fan of the corn mix that came with it, and overall portion was small considering the price (36$!).  I would be quite disappointed if I came here hungry, but since I've been snacking throughout the day, I was quite full from what we ordered.  Overall a great, but expensive, dinner experience!
Best and most beautiful service I have ever had in a restaurant. Perfect vibe to the place. Great food that felt like modern French. Wonderful part of town.

Just a note about the reservation issue I had, opentable is garbage when it comes to this restaurant.  Its a 30 day lead time to make the reservation.  I checked open table 8am Eastern exactly 30 days before my intended reservation and they said no tables available.  I even tried this at 12:01am and got the same result.  To get a table, call.  Pay the international toll from the US to Canada and call.  I even left a message around 1:45pm 30 days before my reservation date and they called back around 2:30pm.   I will follow up at the end of July when we actually visit.  (FYI, I usually love opentable, I've collected my share of $25 checks from them with all the reservations I made on the site.  But for Garde Manger...not so much)

Great ambiance and the food was delicious. I started with the Old Pal drink which was great if you like rye whiskey. I had an appetizer sample of their fresh oysters which were very good. My wife got the char with squash purée, bacon and brussel sprouts.  I got the pork tenderloin with red cabbage and jalapeño grits.  Both meals were amazing. The char and pork were each cooked perfectly. We had a basket of bread as well that was fantastic- chewy on the inside, crusty on the outside. It came with an herb butter. For dessert we got a warm apple galette with brown butter ice cream. We were full from dinner but the dessert was worth it. The restaurant is on the pricier side but perfect for a special occasion night out.

Dined at Garde Manger for the first time last night. The food was absolutely delicious!It is now considered one of our favourite dinners (the presentation of food included). Welcoming, friendly service along with a great atmosphere enhanced the dining experience. Way to go Chuck Hughes and staff!!

SOOOOOOOOOOOO GOOD!The ambiance of Garde-Manger is fantastic.  Warm and cozy, and all of the guests are excited to be dining in noteworthy establishment.  The waitstaff is extremely knowledgeable and friendly.For appetizers, we shared the mid-sized lobster poutine and it was amazing!!!  Everything about it was perfect.  The lobster was incredibly fresh, the gravy was hearty and the fries were not to soggy or too cripsy.For main course, I split the scallops with potato gnocci and the stuffed cornish hen with my friend.  The scallops were cooked perfectly, and tender and flavourful.  The cornish hen was also amazing (it was super juicy).For dessert we shared the fried Mars bar.  Which was completely gluttonous, but the perfect sweet way to top off an otherwise savory meal.I would definitely highly recommend Garde-Manger and look forward to returning!
